Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reconstructing ancient passive margin dynamics by relating geomorphic and stratigraphic surfaces: a combined laboratory and field study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to carry out a lab and field investigation of statistics describing the stratigraphic architecture of passive continental margins and their relationship to geomorphic surfaces. The overall objective of the project is to improve our ability to invert the stratigraphic record for paleo surfaces dynamics and topography. The continental margin record contains features such as bars, channels and channel networks, yet we cannot precisely reconstruct the relationship between these preserved deposits and geomorphic processes that produce them. Thus, the research plan is to use flume models to measure and identify scaling relationships in channelized, distributive systems with a focus on deltaic and deep water systems. The goal is determine how stratigraphic discontinuities are formed and to see if the mechanism of formation can be deduced from statistical descriptions of surface morphology. The ultimate objective is be able to infer the dynamic origin of fossilized erosional surfaces, using relationships derived from the experimental flume models.

The stated broader impacts include student training. The work also has practical value in understanding how coastal systems grow, as well as in resource extraction from the deltaic and deep-water systems. The results could have important implications in how we interpret stratigraphic surfaces in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While it is true that at many scales the stratigraphic record contains significant temporal gaps it is also true that alluvial basins contain the most complete record of information necessary to quantitatively reconstruct paleolandscape dynamics for the majority of Earth History. As such, developing methods for quantifying stratigraphic completeness is critical for constraining the precision of information we hope to extract. In addition, these basins house important groundwater and energy resources. This project focused on determining what controls both the completeness of the stratigraphic record and the relationship between stratigraphic surfaces and the paleo-Earth surfaces that formed them. Using a combination of physical and numerical experiments, in addition to analysis of data from field scale systems we demonstrated how the water and sediment supply to a delta, in addition to the cohesion of sediment comprising deltas influence the fidelity of the stratigraphic record. We found that as the amount of water relative to sediment entering a delta increased, the completeness of the stratigraphic record decreased. We also found that the completeness of the stratigraphic record decreased as channel depths increased and subsidence rates decreased. In addition, we found that systems with high sediment cohesion generate depositional features (stratigraphic architecture) that could be confused with signals of changing climate (sea-level). Our results help place quantitative limits on the scales of stratigraphic products that could be produced without changing climate. These results are already being used by a suite of scientists studying topics as diverse as how we model evolution to how we build hydrocarbon reservoir models.

Work performed in this project has helped fund the graduate education of two students, summer research projects of 2 undergraduate students, the construction of the Tulane Sediment Dynamics lab by PI Straub who was an early career faculty member when this project began, and generation of data sets that have been shared with the teaching community for in-class practicals. In addition, this project helped foster a relationship with ExxonMobil and work geared towards validating their forward stratigraphic models.
